pageDescription: An interactive educational tool to calculate and explore the bijective base-6 number system, which has no zero. Features a live converter and reference tables.
liveConverterDesc: Enter a decimal number to see its real-time representation across different systems.
calculatorDesc: Enter two bijective base-6 numbers to see the results for all operations.
quizDesc: Test your skills! Solve the problem to see if you've mastered the system.
quizIncorrect: Not quite! The correct answer was {answer}.
primerDesc1: Most number systems we use are positional. This means a digit's value depends on its position. The "base" tells us how many unique digits are used. The value of each position is an exponent of the base, starting from 0 on the right.
primerDesc2: In these standard systems, the digit zero is essential. It is not just a number, but a fundamental placeholder. It signifies an empty position, like the tens place in 101. The bijective system is fascinating because it works without this placeholder.
explanationDesc1: This system is a bijective base-6 numeration. It is positional, but with two key differences: it has no zero, and its digits run from 1 to 6. Because there is no zero to act as a placeholder, the system "rolls over" differently. After 6, the next number is 11.
algoDesc1: The trick to converting from decimal to bijective base-6 is to temporarily shift the number system. Computers naturally work with remainders from 0 to 5, but our digits are 1 to 6. We bridge this gap by subtracting 1 before each calculation.
visualizerDesc: Enter a decimal number to see the conversion algorithm in action.
appDesc1: Bijective numeration is more than a curiosity; it solves real-world problems in computer science.
appSpreadsheet: Spreadsheet Columns: Microsoft Excel and Google Sheets use a bijective base-26 system (A-Z). After Z comes AA, then AB. This is a perfect real-world example where there is no "zeroth" column.
appUrl: URL Shorteners: Services like bit.ly use a bijective base-62 system (a-z, A-Z, 0-9) to map massive database IDs to short, unique strings.
appFingerCounting: Finger Counting: While humans can count to 10 on their fingers, a bijective system allows for much higher counts. By assigning values 1-6 to different finger positions, one could easily count to 6^10 (over 60 million) using just their hands!
advFactorizationTitle: A Note on 'Composite' Digits and Factorization
advFactorizationDesc: An astute observer of the multiplication table will notice something curious: 2 Ã— 3 = 6, but also 1 Ã— 6 = 6. In our standard number system, the number 6 has a unique prime factorization (2 and 3). However, in the bijective system, the digit 6 itself acts like a composite number. The digits 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 are the "primes" of this single-digit world. This reveals a deep property: the set of single digits in a bijective system does not form a Unique Factorization Domain. This is a direct consequence of using the base `k` as a digit instead of `0`.
advFormalLangDesc: The bijective base-6 system has a beautiful connection to theoretical computer science. If we define an alphabet of symbols, Î£ (Sigma), as our set of digits {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, then the set of all possible finite strings you can create with these symbols is called the Kleene Star, denoted Î£*. The bijective system is a perfect, ordered enumeration of this set.
advGeoDesc: We can visualize the entire system as an infinite, complete 6-ary tree, where every node has exactly six children. The root represents a starting point. The first level of nodes are labeled 1 through 6. In this model, every bijective base-6 number is the unique "address" or path from the root to a specific node.
